articles.title: About this site
articles.description: Some additional details about the website

articles.title: Curriculum Vitae
articles.contents:
Jesse A. Flowers
Adkerson School of Accountancy
Mississippi State University
Jesseflow99@gmail.com






library(caret)
trainIndex <- createDataPartition(bankdata$Bankrupt., p = .6, list = FALSE, times = 1)



Grab The Data


#grab the data
BankTrain <- bankdata[ trainIndex,]
BankTest  <- bankdata[-trainIndex,]



Perform PreProcessing on Data


preProcValues <- preProcess(BankTrain, method = c("center", "scale"))

trainTransformed <- predict(preProcValues, BankTrain)

preProcValues <- preProcess(BankTest, method = c("center", "scale"))

testTransformed <- predict(preProcValues, BankTest)
psych::describe(testTransformed)


                                                        vars    n

Fit KNN


set.seed(1)

BankRF<- train(
  form = factor(Bankrupt.) ~ .,
  data = BankTrain,
  #here we add classProbs because we want probs
  trControl = trainControl(method = "cv", number = 10,
                           classProbs =  TRUE),
  method = "rf",
  tuneLength = 3)#why 3?

BankRF


Random Forest 

4092 samples
  95 predictor
   2 classes: 'No', 'Yes' 

No pre-processing
Resampling: Cross-Validated (10 fold) 
Summary of sample sizes: 3683, 3683, 3682, 3683, 3683, 3682, ... 
Resampling results across tuning parameters:

  mtry  Accuracy   Kappa    
   2    0.9701867  0.1850996
  48    0.9696983  0.2601388
  95    0.9687220  0.2417229

Accuracy was used to select the optimal model using the
 largest value.
The final value used for the model was mtry = 2.

Use the test set to make a prediction


Bank_pred<-predict(BankRF,testTransformed)
head(BankRF)


$method
[1] "rf"

$modelInfo
$modelInfo$label
[1] "Random Forest"

$modelInfo$library
[1] "randomForest"

$modelInfo$loop
NULL

$modelInfo$type
[1] "Classification" "Regression"    

$modelInfo$parameters
  parameter   class                         label
1      mtry numeric #Randomly Selected Predictors

$modelInfo$grid
function(x, y, len = NULL, search = "grid") {
                    if(search == "grid") {
                      out <- data.frame(mtry = caret::var_seq(p = ncol(x),
                                                              classification = is.factor(y),
                                                              len = len))
                    } else {
                      out <- data.frame(mtry = unique(sample(1:ncol(x), size = len, replace = TRUE)))
                    }
                  }

$modelInfo$fit
function(x, y, wts, param, lev, last, classProbs, ...)
                    randomForest::randomForest(x, y, mtry = min(param$mtry, ncol(x)), ...)
<bytecode: 0x000000002ea58248>

$modelInfo$predict
function(modelFit, newdata, submodels = NULL)
                    if(!is.null(newdata)) predict(modelFit, newdata) else predict(modelFit)
<bytecode: 0x00000000302eb938>

$modelInfo$prob
function(modelFit, newdata, submodels = NULL)
                    if(!is.null(newdata)) predict(modelFit, newdata, type = "prob") else predict(modelFit, type = "prob")
<bytecode: 0x000000002fe5a570>

$modelInfo$predictors
function(x, ...) {
                    ## After doing some testing, it looks like randomForest
                    ## will only try to split on plain main effects (instead
                    ## of interactions or terms like I(x^2).
                    varIndex <- as.numeric(names(table(x$forest$bestvar)))
                    varIndex <- varIndex[varIndex > 0]
                    varsUsed <- names(x$forest$ncat)[varIndex]
                    varsUsed
                  }

$modelInfo$varImp
function(object, ...){
                    varImp <- randomForest::importance(object, ...)
                    if(object$type == "regression") {
                      if("%IncMSE" %in% colnames(varImp)) {
                        varImp <- as.data.frame(varImp[,"%IncMSE", drop = FALSE])
                        colnames(varImp) <- "Overall"
                      } else {
                        varImp <- as.data.frame(varImp[,1, drop = FALSE])
                        colnames(varImp) <- "Overall"
                      }
                    }
                    else {
                      retainNames <- levels(object$y)
                      if(all(retainNames %in% colnames(varImp))) {
                        varImp <- varImp[, retainNames, drop = FALSE]
                      } else {
                        varImp <- as.data.frame(varImp[,1, drop = FALSE])
                        colnames(varImp) <- "Overall"
                      }
                    }

                    out <- as.data.frame(varImp, stringsAsFactors = TRUE)
                    if(dim(out)[2] == 2) {
                      tmp <- apply(out, 1, mean)
                      out[,1] <- out[,2] <- tmp
                    }
                    out
                  }

$modelInfo$levels
function(x) x$classes

$modelInfo$tags
[1] "Random Forest"              "Ensemble Model"            
[3] "Bagging"                    "Implicit Feature Selection"

$modelInfo$sort
function(x) x[order(x[,1]),]

$modelInfo$oob
function(x) {
                    out <- switch(x$type,
                                  regression =   c(sqrt(max(x$mse[length(x$mse)], 0)), x$rsq[length(x$rsq)]),
                                  classification =  c(1 - x$err.rate[x$ntree, "OOB"],
                                                      e1071::classAgreement(x$confusion[,-dim(x$confusion)[2]])[["kappa"]]))
                    names(out) <- if(x$type == "regression") c("RMSE", "Rsquared") else c("Accuracy", "Kappa")
                    out
                  }


$modelType
[1] "Classification"

$results
  mtry  Accuracy     Kappa  AccuracySD    KappaSD
1    2 0.9701867 0.1850996 0.002231980 0.09865734
2   48 0.9696983 0.2601388 0.005169602 0.14963773
3   95 0.9687220 0.2417229 0.006272886 0.15321894

$pred
NULL

$bestTune
  mtry
1    2

articles.title: K Nearest Neighbors (KNN)
articles.contents:
Jesse A. Flowers
Adkerson School of Accountancy
Mississippi State University
Jesseflow99@gmail.com

(KNN) Using Iris Data Set
Split The Data 60/40


library(caret)
?createDataPartition
trainIndex <- createDataPartition(iris$Species, p = .6, list = FALSE, times = 1)



Grab The Data


#grab the data
irisTrain <- iris[ trainIndex,]
irisTest  <- iris[-trainIndex,]



Perform PreProcessing on Data


preProcValues <- preProcess(irisTrain, method = c("center", "scale"))

trainTransformed <- predict(preProcValues, irisTrain)

preProcValues <- preProcess(irisTest, method = c("center", "scale"))

testTransformed <- predict(preProcValues, irisTest)
psych::describe(testTransformed)


             vars  n mean   sd median trimmed  mad   min  max range
Sepal.Length    1 60    0 1.00  -0.01   -0.03 1.28 -1.79 2.35  4.14
Sepal.Width     2 60    0 1.00  -0.01   -0.03 1.00 -1.91 2.70  4.61
Petal.Length    3 60    0 1.00   0.35    0.01 0.98 -1.55 1.54  3.09
Petal.Width     4 60    0 1.00   0.18   -0.02 1.22 -1.39 1.63  3.03
Species*        5 60    2 0.82   2.00    2.00 1.48  1.00 3.00  2.00
              skew kurtosis   se
Sepal.Length  0.16    -0.88 0.13
Sepal.Width   0.30    -0.20 0.13
Petal.Length -0.29    -1.50 0.13
Petal.Width  -0.09    -1.38 0.13
Species*      0.00    -1.55 0.11

Fit KNN


knn_fit<-train(Species~.,
               data=trainTransformed,
               method="knn",
               tuneGrid=data.frame(k=5))

knn_fit


k-Nearest Neighbors 

90 samples
 4 predictor
 3 classes: 'setosa', 'versicolor', 'virginica' 

No pre-processing
Resampling: Bootstrapped (25 reps) 
Summary of sample sizes: 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, 90, ... 
Resampling results:

  Accuracy   Kappa    
  0.9281432  0.8912382

Tuning parameter 'k' was held constant at a value of 5

Use the test set to make a prediction


knn_pred<-predict(knn_fit,testTransformed)
head(knn_pred)


[1] setosa setosa setosa setosa setosa setosa
Levels: setosa versicolor virginica

Run ConfusionMatrix


confusionMatrix(knn_pred,testTransformed$Species)


Confusion Matrix and Statistics

            Reference
Prediction   setosa versicolor virginica
  setosa         20          0         0
  versicolor      0         18         2
  virginica       0          2        18

Overall Statistics
                                         
               Accuracy : 0.9333         
                 95% CI : (0.838, 0.9815)
    No Information Rate : 0.3333         
    P-Value [Acc > NIR] : < 2.2e-16      
                                         
                  Kappa : 0.9            
                                         
 Mcnemar's Test P-Value : NA             

Statistics by Class:

                     Class: setosa Class: versicolor Class: virginica
Sensitivity                 1.0000            0.9000           0.9000
Specificity                 1.0000            0.9500           0.9500
Pos Pred Value              1.0000            0.9000           0.9000
Neg Pred Value              1.0000            0.9500           0.9500
Prevalence                  0.3333            0.3333           0.3333
Detection Rate              0.3333            0.3000           0.3000
Detection Prevalence        0.3333            0.3333           0.3333
Balanced Accuracy           1.0000            0.9250           0.9250

articles.title: Resume
articles.contents:
Jesse A. Flowers
Adkerson School of Accountancy
Mississippi State University
Jesseflow99@gmail.com

EMPLOYMENT
Miles Tax Service,
Starkville, MS — Accountant February 2020- May 2021
Walmart,
Starkville, MS — Automotive Associate May 2018- March 2020
Car Wash USA,
Olive Branch, MS — Supervisor/Key Holder April 2015 -August 2018
EDUCATION
Mississippi State University, Starkville, MS,
Master of Taxation (Minor in Data Analytics)
Graduation Date July 2022
Mississippi State University, Starkville, MS,
Bachelors of Accountancy
Graduation Date April 2021
Skills and Abilities
• Advised clients on business and personal tax decisions.
• Resolved tax issues for corporate and personal tax clients.
• Obtained extensive experience in multiple computer programs such as QuickBooks, Proseries, and Excel.
• Executed large collaborative projects.
• Written and oral communication skills.
• Excellent collaborative skills.
Honors and Organizations
• Accounting and Finance Student Society of Mississippi State University
• President’s list at Mississippi State

articles.title: Rsquared
articles.description: RSquared can be a very misleading predictor
articles.contents:
Possible Issues from R-Squared
R-Squared does a poor job of measure fit. Even when a model is completely correct, it can still be a relativity low fit. Alternatively when a model is incorrect, R-Squared could be still be very close to 1.
Time to blow RSquared up1 💥
R-squared is a statistic that often accompanies regression output. It ranges in value from 0 to 1 and is usually interpreted as summarizing the percent of variation in the response that the regression model explains. So an R-squared of 0.65 might mean that the model explains about 65% of the variation in our dependent variable. Given this logic, we prefer our regression models have a high R-squared.
In R, we typically get R-squared by calling the summary function on a model object. Here’s a quick example using simulated data:


# independent variable
x <- 1:20 
# for reproducibility
set.seed(1) 
# dependent variable; function of x with random error
y <- 2 + 0.5*x + rnorm(20,0,3) 
# simple linear regression
mod <- lm(y~x)
# request just the r-squared value
summary(mod)$r.squared          


[1] 0.6026682

One way to express R-squared is as the sum of squared fitted-value deviations divided by the sum of squared original-value deviations:
\[
R^{2} =  \frac{\sum (\hat{y} – \bar{\hat{y}})^{2}}{\sum (y – \bar{y})^{2}}
\]
We can calculate it directly using our model object like so:


# extract fitted (or predicted) values from model
f <- mod$fitted.values
# sum of squared fitted-value deviations
mss <- sum((f - mean(f))^2)
# sum of squared original-value deviations
tss <- sum((y - mean(y))^2)
# r-squared
mss/tss                      


[1] 0.6026682

R-squared does not measure goodness of fit. It can be arbitrarily low when the model is completely correct. By making\(σ^2\) large, we drive R-squared towards 0, even when every assumption of the simple linear regression model is correct in every particular.
What is \(σ^2\)? When we perform linear regression, we assume our model almost predicts our dependent variable. The difference between “almost” and “exact” is assumed to be a draw from a Normal distribution with mean 0 and some variance we call \(σ^2\).
This statement is easy enough to demonstrate. The way we do it here is to create a function that (1) generates data meeting the assumptions of simple linear regression (independent observations, normally distributed errors with constant variance), (2) fits a simple linear model to the data, and (3) reports the R-squared. Notice the only parameter for sake of simplicity is sigma. We then “apply” this function to a series of increasing \(σ\) values and plot the results.


r2.0 <- function(sig){
  # our predictor
  x <- seq(1,10,length.out = 100)   
  # our response; a function of x plus some random noise
  y <- 2 + 1.2*x + rnorm(100,0,sd = sig) 
  # print the R-squared value
  summary(lm(y ~ x))$r.squared          
}
sigmas <- seq(0.5,20,length.out = 20)
 # apply our function to a series of sigma values
rout <- sapply(sigmas, r2.0)            
plot(rout ~ sigmas, type="b")




R-squared tanks hard with increasing sigma, even though the model is completely correct in every respect.
R-squared can be arbitrarily close to 1 when the model is totally wrong.
The point being made is that R-squared does not measure goodness of fit.


set.seed(1)
# our predictor is data from an exponential distribution
x <- rexp(50,rate=0.005)
# non-linear data generation
y <- (x-1)^2 * runif(50, min=0.8, max=1.2) 
# clearly non-linear
plot(x,y)             






summary(lm(y ~ x))$r.squared


[1] 0.8485146

It’s very high at about 0.85, but the model is completely wrong. Using R-squared to justify the “goodness” of our model in this instance would be a mistake. Hopefully one would plot the data first and recognize that a simple linear regression in this case would be inappropriate.
Possible Solutions
Mean Square Error (MSE) is much more effective when used to measure prediciton error

https://data.library.virginia.edu/is-r-squared-useless/↩︎
